pages.text: Mirasaura is a fascinating little reptile recently described from the Grès à Voltzia Formation of France. It is not only interesting in its own right, but also noteworthy for helping solve the long-standing mystery that is Longisquama. That animal, known from only one partial specimen, has remained contentious for over 50 years, with uncertain taxonomic position and unusual anatomy.

In particular, the large, filamentous structures present in Longisquama have attracted a myriad of hypotheses, explaining them as everything from true feathers to unassociated plant fossils. The discovery of Mirasaura shows that those filaments are indeed a genuine anatomical feature of Longisquama and its close relatives. Not only that, but they appear to have been a novel integumentary structure of this clade, not homologous to scales or feathers.

Mirasaura shows phylogenetic affinity to other Triassic weirdos such as Drepanosaurus, tying Longisquama into the drepanosauromorph clade. While such a relationship has been suggested before, this additional evidence from Mirasaura limits plausible alternatives, suggesting that Longisquama has finally found its home in the reptile family tree.
